handNote.p: Main scribe from 107v to end of 116v.

Main scribe from very top of 117r to end of homily on 122v, exclusive of the added doxology. A 'less good but nearly contemporary hand' (Ker 206-210); i.e., a 'compressed' hand (Magennis 7-8). Digipal assigns 117r-122v to DP630 but the hand is different, as noted by Magennis, Ker and Clemoes. Many appearances of tall e ligature and tall s, macron for abbreviations resembles two dots, frequent use of squarey two-stroke unroofed a with flat top.

Correcting hand often using double-punctus markings, adds doxology, active only in select items in Julius E VII, named J3 by Magennis (9-10) and described by G.I. Needham, 'Additions and Alterations in Cotton MS. Julius E VII', Review of English Studies, New Series 9 (1958): 160-4.
Correcting hand using comma-shaped/caret-like markings, active throughout Julius E VII, named J2 by Magennis (Magennis 8).
